variant.bodyText: The 19th Annual Meeting of the Association for Computational Linguistics will be held at Stanford University, Stanford, California, from Monday, June 29, through Wednesday, July 1, 1981. Papers are being solicited on linguistically and computationally significant topics, including the following:
variant.listItem: . syntax, parsing, and sentence generation, . computational semantics (including reference, anaphora, metaphor), • discourse analysis and speech acts, • representation of knowledge, deduction, planning, and plan recognition, as they relate to language understanding, • speech analysis and synthesis, • machine translation and machine-aided transla- tion, • mathematical foundations of computational lin- guistics, and • linguistic theories and their computational appli- cations.
variant.bodyText: Authors wishing to present a paper should submit six copies of a 5 to 8 page summary, double-spaced, by February 2, 1981 to: C. Raymond Perrault, Bolt Beranek and Newman, 50 Moulton Street, Cambridge, Mass. 02138 [phone: (617) 491-1850; ARPAnet: RPerrault@bbna]. All submissions will be read by the program com- mittee, which is chaired by C. Raymond Perrault, Uni- versity of Toronto (on leave at SRI International and BBN), and consists of Bertram Bruce, Bolt Beranek and Newman, Jaime Carbonnell, Carnegie-Mellon Uni- versity, Mitchell Marcus, Bell Labs, Ellen Prince, Uni- versity of Pennsylvania, and Ralph Weischedel, Univer- sity of Delaware. It is important that the summary convey the new ideas and contain sufficient information to allow the program committee to determine the scope of the work, including references to the relevant literature. Summaries exceeding 8 double-spaced pages in length may not receive the attention they deserve. Authors will be notified of the acceptance of their papers by March 16, 1981. Full-length versions of accepted papers submitted by April 27, 1981 to the program committee chairman will be included in the
variant.reference: Proceedings of the Conference. Local arrangements are being handled by Jerry Kaplan, Computer Science Department, Stanford Uni- versity, Stanford, Calif. 94305 [phone: (415) 497- 1422; ARPAnet: Kaplan@sri]. For further information contact Don Walker, SRI International, Menlo Park, Calif. 94025 [phone: (415) 859-3071; ARPAnet: walker@sri].
variant.page: 192 American Journal of Computational Linguistics, Volume 6, Number 3-4, July-December 1980
